title: Refactor (isort, black)
body:
# Refactoring Coding Style (Black/Isort)

What do we think about starting to use tools such as [black](https://github.com/psf/black) and [isort](https://github.com/PyCQA/isort) for readability/maintainability purposes?

I think this is a good part of our first steps towards a more maintainable code base that follows modern pythonic standards.

## What this PR contains
- I ran `isort .` on the codebase
- I ran `black shap tests` on the codebase
- I added static checkers on our CICD pipeline to check that the `shap` and `tests` directories are compliant

## 18 thousand changes? why?....

I'm looking to open a PR that adds static typing to help make SHAP a little more robust, however tasks like that would be easier if we had a standardised code style (enforced by tools such as black and isort).

Pros:
- Standardised code style that's become quite pythonic in recent years (almost everyone uses black)
- Cleaner/More readable code/imports

Cons:
- Annoying to current devs who would have painful merge conflicts

## What current PR owners should do INSTEAD of merging

run the following on their code base:
```
isort .
black shap tests
```
This would reduce merge conflicts significantly.
